levels.start_text: In the beginning, there was nothing... nothing but zero, a ball, a field, and a hole with a flag. Mostly nothing, though.
levels.end_text: Not very interesting, right?

levels.start_text: Well, let's spice it up a bit. How about a new number? Let's call it one. And hey, now you aren't right on top of the hole!
levels.end_text: What about MORE numbers?

levels.start_text: With just zero and one at our hands, we are able to create all kinds of numbers! Now, try to reach this goal, number by number.
levels.end_text: What if we could somehow combine these numbers together?

levels.start_text: We can! In fact, the act of playing move after move has already implicitly acted as addition, our first operator! Try to do this level in only one move!
levels.end_text: Sure that's fun, but is there an opposite to addition?

levels.start_text: If addition is when you add one number's value to another, then subtraction is when you take one number's value away from another! But be careful, this may be dangerous for our numbers...
levels.end_text: Congratulations, you kept all the numbers safe and sound! And that, my friends, is the end of the story of numbers...

levels.start_text: Wait, what?
levels.end_text: Where did we go?

levels.start_text: What you just discovered is negative numbers! If we want to play the game of subtraction, we need to include these. Let's call our numbers 'integers' now. See if you can reach this next hole!
levels.end_text: Let's see what other games the numbers can play.

levels.start_text: This might get repetitive...
levels.end_text: Is there a faster way of doing this?

levels.start_text: There is! Multiplication is when we repeatedly add the same number together!
levels.end_text: How would this work with negative numbers, though?

levels.start_text: Time to find out!
levels.end_text: Great job! In fact, there were multiple ways to complete that level.. but I'm sure the one you chose was good enough.

levels.start_text: Now, what happens when you combine two negatives together? Try to only use negative numbers on this level.
levels.end_text: When you multiply negatives, they cancel each other out and the product becomes positive!

levels.start_text: Remember how we introduced multiplication with repeated addition? Well, how about repeated multiplication?
levels.end_text: When a number is multiplied by itself some number of times, this becomes its own operation called exponentiation. The number being multiplied is the base, and the number of times it's multiplied by itself is the power. Here, we've raised 2 to the power of 3!

levels.start_text: We'll now refer to powers with its own symbol, the carat (^). Play around with them and see if you can reach the hole!
levels.end_text: Now you're a master of integers! But can we go further?

levels.start_text: What happens when we use a negative number as the power?
levels.end_text: What was that?

levels.start_text: Well, first: remember how we introduced subtraction as the opposite of addition? How about the opposite of multiplication? Introducing division: multiplication in reverse. See if you can figure this hole out!
levels.end_text: The hole wasn't aligned perfectly to the grid, but with division, we were able to get there anyway. Division opens up a whole new set of numbers: the rationals! And, it turns out that you used them already in the last level!

levels.start_text: Let's keep playing with rational numbers!
levels.end_text: Good work!

levels.start_text: Now, remember our friend, the carat (^)? What happens when you use that with a rational number as the power?
levels.end_text: Well, what you just discovered is irrational numbers! Unlike rational numbers, these cannot be represented by fractions with whole numerators and denominators. But, combined with rational numbers, these encompass the set of real numbers!

levels.start_text: You can produce these numbers with certain operations, like our new friend, the square root (sqrt). Come to think of it, you already used this in the last puzzle! See if you can solve this one with sqrt.
levels.end_text: Good work! The square root of 2 is a famous irrational number. There's a couple more like it, though, which we'll explore in the next few levels.

levels.start_text: Did someone say pie? Oh, you meant pi... oops. Well, pi, or 3.14159... is another famous irrational number which comes up in a lot of contexts. It is related to the ratio of a circle's circumference over its diameter (while that sounds rational, it definitely isn't!). See if you can solve this puzzle with pi!
levels.end_text: You should become a baker! It's not real pie, but maybe someone would appreciate it.

levels.start_text: One more special irrational we'll look at is e, or Euler's number. This number is particularly important in calculus, which we won't get into, but just know that it comes up in a lot of contexts also. Its actual value is roughly 2.7182818..., for those curious.
levels.end_text: We now pronounce you master of reals! You now know every real number, from the naturals to the integers, to the rationals, and even the irrationals. But is that all we can do? What if there was something more? Something beyond? What if there was... another dimension?

levels.start_text: But how do we get there? And what happens when we put a negative in a square root? Surely these questions aren't related, though.
levels.end_text: Or... they were! How convenient. What you've just discovered is imaginary numbers. The imaginary unit, i, is the square root of -1, which would be undefined if not for our new definition. We can use i to expand past the real number line into a two-dimensional complex plane!

levels.start_text: But what is that word, "complex"? What happens when we combine our real numbers and imaginary numbers? (Use i to refer to imaginaries from here on.)
levels.end_text: What you've just done is created a complex number! 2+3i is like a coordinate pair, with 2 being the real part and 3i being the imaginary part. Combine them together, and you can move anywhere in the complex plane!

levels.start_text: Now try this puzzle for size. Enter complex numbers exactly as they're listed.
levels.end_text: Great work!

levels.start_text: How about this next one?
levels.end_text: Keep up the great work!

levels.start_text: I can tell you're getting tired. Don't worry, there's just a couple more puzzles left. Try this one!
levels.end_text: Superb. You're so close to the finish line!

levels.start_text: Here's one last challenge for you: see if you can get to this hole! Be careful which complex numbers you use.
levels.end_text: It's been a long road, dear player. With great pleasure, we pronounce you a certifiable math expert. Maybe you never wanted to be one, but here you are nonetheless. Bask in your own glory; you've earned it. Congratulations on completing Math Minigolf!
